awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Design Science for CPS
awd_abstract_narration:
A CPS is a system in which computer-based (?cyber?) technology is combined with all kinds of physical systems, such as planes and robotic-surgeons. CPSs require integration (in industry and academia) of different types of knowledge from many different domains. CPSs are built from often inaccurate, undependable components, and operate in harsh and unpredictable environments. The cyber domain, interfaces, and the physical domain are tightly interwoven and networked (distributed) and hence cannot be designed and optimized individually. The goal of this project is to create a general CPS design-science that makes the design of every CPS simpler, faster, and more dependable, while at the same time reducing the cost and the required expertise level. This project gives rise to a unified theory that can allow for specification, modeling, design, optimization, and verification of CPSs on different levels of design abstraction and different steps of projection, even across boundaries between varied technologies. The project does bridge the gap between the continuous-time physical domain and the discrete timed cyber system.


This project has a broad and profound impact in scientific, engineering, industrial, and academic communities. By enabling a fundamentally efficient design of CPSs, the most limiting bottleneck in design technology is eliminated, paving the way for many new applications and jobs with significant economic and social impact. This project contributes to the on-line educational endeavors currently underway, allowing cross education in different disciplines of complex CPS and speeding up development of new CPS programs in engineering and computer science.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to address a number of key challenges in the design of Cyber Physical Systems and create a general design-science that makes design of every CPS simpler, faster, dependable, and low cost. Specifically, the goals of the project were:

(1) a unified theory (design-science) for CPSs to allow specification, modeling, design and optimization,

(2) a design methodology for CPS that builds on the above unified theory,

(3) a fundamental change in the target platforms and devices, and

(4) a new strategy and technology for CPS education.

During the project, we addressed the project goals in four stages:

  • First, the project studied the properties and characteristics of Cyber-physical Systems as a whole to improve the understanding of the field. The results include a well-received survey paper about CPSs, as well as a range of technical papers addressing intervals, faults, and timing properties of CPSs.
  • Second, we build a framework to assess and evaluate the static and dynamic properties of the cyber and the physical parts of CPSs. This composition framework serves as our top-level design tool capturing all the various research activities. The input of the framework is a behavioral model of the cyber physical system and a set of constraints. The framework utilizes CoDeL: a component-based description language that allows system designers to express physical and cyber components as reusable building blocks of the system with their parameterizable properties, models, and interconnectivity. The framework integrates established approaches and solvers for embedded systems, such as integer linear programming (ILP) and satisfiability (SAT) solvers to facilitates efficient search and optimization of the CPS design space. With the framework we pioneered the idea of a holistic design space exploration of cyber-physical system – including the physical, the control, and the cyber aspects of the system.
  • Third, we studied and developed specific technical solutions for principle issues in the development of CPSs. The technical results contributed towards our framework. Examples for those technical solutions are:
    • Providing hardware support for solving of differential equations in real time.
    • The application of control theory to steer design decisions in the system building process.
    • Ensured correct operations of the CPS applications in presence data, sensor and process anomalies.
    • Robust scheduling of real-time tasks in presence of platform uncertainties and transient overload situations.
  • Fourth, we disseminated our findings, including the framework for a range of practical applications and to improve the education of cyber-phyiscal systems. 
  • The applications include:
    • A device for real-world testing of medical ventilators.
    • ECG-based biometric authentication that utilizes physical body properties to ensure safety and security in body area sensor networks.
    • Timing attack aware high-level synthesis of integrated circuits by changing the open source LegUp HLS tool to mitigate physical side-channel attacks.
    • Heating ventilation and air-conditioning system that works correctly in presence of sensor faults.

The project teaching outcomes were disseminated as follows:

  • An automated learning management tool in an engineering course based on interdisciplinary metrics.
  • Web-based online programming framework and virtual lab which allows students to program and interact with a CPS on different levels of abstractions.
  • Two graduate level courses (CS 245, EECS 225) as well as an undergraduate level course (CS 145 A/B) at UCI
  • Several undergraduate and graduate MS students have been exposed to research. The students have had the opportunity to contribute to research activities and author academic papers.
  • Three graduate Students submitted and successfully defended their PhD theses.
